1.name: Primary Somatosensory Cortex (BA 1)
structure: Located in the postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe
Occupies the crown/apex of the postcentral gyrus
Contains dense granular layer IV with high density of sensory neurons
Receives projections from ventral posterior lateral nucleus of thalamus
function: Processes tactile sensations including fine touch and pressure discrimination
Maintains somatotopic representation of contralateral body (sensory homunculus)
Specializes in texture discrimination and proprioceptive feedback
Damage results in contralateral tactile agnosia and impaired two-point discrimination

2.name: Primary Somatosensory Cortex (BA 2)
structure: Located in the posterior aspect of the postcentral gyrus
Borders the postcentral sulcus and adjoins BA 1 anteriorly
Contains slightly less dense granular layer IV compared to BA 1
Receives projections from thalamus and integrates input from BA 1 and BA 3
function: Specialized in proprioception and sense of position
Processes tactile information related to size and shape discrimination
Integrates sensory input from multiple receptors for complex tactile recognition
Contributes to stereognosis (recognition of objects by touch alone)

3.name: Primary Somatosensory Cortex (BA 3)
structure: Located on the anterior part of the postcentral gyrus, adjacent to central sulcus
Subdivided into BA 3a (deep in sulcus) and BA 3b (on surface)
BA 3a receives primarily proprioceptive input, BA 3b receives cutaneous input
Most granular cortex of the somatosensory areas with prominent layer IV
function: Serves as the primary receptor zone for somatosensory input
Processes basic tactile sensations and discriminative touch
Maintains detailed somatotopic organization (fine representation of fingers and lips)
Damage results in contralateral hemihypesthesia (decreased tactile sensation)

4.name: Primary Motor Cortex (BA 4)
structure: Located on the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobe, anterior to central sulcus
Contains giant pyramidal cells of Betz in layer V that form the corticospinal tract
Organized somatotopically as motor homunculus (legs medial, face lateral)
Agranular cortex with poorly developed layer IV and prominent layer V
function: Controls voluntary movement execution for the contralateral body
Encodes movement parameters including direction, force, and speed
Forms direct monosynaptic connections with spinal motor neurons via corticospinal tract
Damage results in contralateral hemiplegia/hemiparesis with upper motor neuron signs

5.name: Somatosensory Association Cortex (BA 5)
structure: Located in the superior parietal lobule, posterior to the postcentral gyrus
Receives projections from primary somatosensory cortex (BA 1, 2, 3)
Contains moderate granular layer IV with association cortex characteristics
Densely connected with other sensory association areas and motor planning regions
function: Integrates tactile and proprioceptive information for stereognosis
Contributes to spatial awareness of body position and limb coordination
Important for skilled manual activities requiring tactile guidance
Damage contributes to tactile agnosia and deficits in hand-eye coordination

6.name: Premotor and Supplementary Motor Cortex (BA 6)
structure: Located anterior to primary motor cortex on the lateral and medial surfaces
Supplementary motor area (SMA) on medial surface, premotor cortex laterally
Larger pyramidal cells than association cortex but smaller than primary motor
Receives input from prefrontal cortex, parietal lobe, and basal ganglia
function: Plans and coordinates complex movement sequences prior to execution
SMA specializes in bimanual coordination and internally-generated movements
Lateral premotor area involved in visually-guided and externally-triggered movements
Damage results in apraxia and difficulty with movement sequencing

7.name: Somatosensory Association Cortex (BA 7)
structure: Located in the posterior parietal cortex, superior parietal lobule
Extends onto both lateral and medial (precuneus) surfaces of the hemisphere
Receives extensive connections from visual, auditory, and somatosensory regions
Well-developed granular layer IV typical of association cortex
function: Integrates multimodal sensory information for spatial awareness
Essential for visuomotor coordination and visually guided reaching/grasping
Contributes to mental rotation and spatial manipulation of objects
Damage results in optic ataxia and deficits in spatial awareness

8.name: Frontal Eye Fields (BA 8)
structure: Located in the middle frontal gyrus and extends onto superior frontal gyrus
Contains moderate-sized pyramidal cells in layer V
Connected to visual cortex, superior colliculus, and brainstem oculomotor nuclei
Borders premotor cortex posteriorly and prefrontal regions anteriorly
function: Controls voluntary saccadic eye movements and visual attention
Involved in anticipatory eye movements and prediction of visual targets
Participates in smooth pursuit eye movements with parietal regions
Unilateral damage results in contralateral gaze preference and impaired saccades

9.name: Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortex (BA 9)
structure: Located in the superior and middle frontal gyri of the prefrontal cortex
Granular prefrontal cortex with well-developed layer IV
Extensive connections with other prefrontal regions, thalamus, and limbic structures
Dense dopaminergic innervation from ventral tegmental area
function: Involved in executive functions, working memory, and attention control
Crucial for planning, decision-making, and cognitive flexibility
Supports monitoring of behavior and integration of information over time
Dysfunction associated with cognitive deficits in schizophrenia and depression

10.name: Anterior Prefrontal Cortex (BA 10)
structure: Located at the frontal pole, most anterior portion of the frontal lobe
Largest single cytoarchitectonic area in human prefrontal cortex
High neuronal density with extensive dendritic arborization
Rich connections with multimodal association areas and limbic structures
function: Supports metacognition, introspection, and self-awareness
Involved in complex cognitive operations like multitasking and prospective memory
Facilitates integration of emotional and cognitive processes
Critical for planning of future actions and evaluation of hypothetical scenarios

11.name: Orbitofrontal Area (BA 11)
structure: Located on the orbital surface of the frontal lobe
Agranular/dysgranular cortex transitioning to mesocortex medially
Receives direct projections from olfactory bulb and primary olfactory cortex
Dense reciprocal connections with amygdala, hypothalamus, and ventral striatum
function: Processes reward value and guides reward-based decision making
Critical for olfactory identification and hedonic evaluation of odors
Involved in emotional regulation and social behavior
Damage associated with impulsivity, disinhibition, and altered personality

12.name: Orbitofrontal Area (BA 12)
structure: Located on the posterior orbital surface, between BA 11 and anterior insula
Transitional zone between orbitofrontal and insular cortex
Thin cortical layers with moderate development of granular layer IV
Connected with anterior insula, temporal pole, and ventromedial prefrontal regions
function: Integrates visceral and gustatory information with emotional processing
Participates in evaluation of food-related stimuli and feeding behavior
Contributes to stimulus-reinforcement association learning
Involved in emotional aspects of decision-making and risk assessment

13.name: Insular Cortex (BA 13)
structure: Located deep within the lateral sulcus, covered by the opercula
Agranular cortex anteriorly transitioning to granular cortex posteriorly
Direct connections with gustatory and visceral afferents
Rich in von Economo neurons in the anterior portion
function: Processes interoceptive information including pain, temperature, and visceral sensations
Integrates gustatory information and contributes to taste perception
Involved in emotional awareness and empathy
Participates in autonomic regulation and visceromotor control

14.name: Insular Cortex (BA 14)
structure: Located in the anterior ventral insula
Agranular cortex with poor laminar differentiation
Connected with amygdala, ventral striatum, and autonomic centers
Contains high concentration of von Economo neurons
function: Processes visceral sensations and interoceptive awareness
Contributes to emotional processing with emphasis on disgust
Participates in autonomic regulation including cardiovascular control
Involved in addiction processes and craving

15.name: Anterior Temporal Lobe (BA 15)
structure: Located in the anterior portion of the middle temporal gyrus
Characterized by moderate granular layer IV
Connected with amygdala, temporal pole, and prefrontal regions
Forms part of the ventral visual stream in primates
function: Involved in semantic processing and conceptual knowledge
Contributes to social cognition and theory of mind
Integrates complex visual features with semantic information
Damage associated with semantic dementia and loss of conceptual knowledge

16.name: Insular Cortex (BA 16)
structure: Located in the posterior insular cortex
Granular cortex with well-defined layer IV
Receives projections from somatosensory thalamus and primary sensory cortices
Connected with secondary somatosensory cortex and posterior parietal areas
function: Processes somatosensory information particularly pain and temperature
Integrates vestibular signals contributing to spatial orientation
Involved in sensorimotor integration and proprioception
Participates in sensory aspects of interoception

17.name: Primary Visual Cortex (BA 17)
structure: Located in the banks of the calcarine sulcus in the occipital lobe
Contains distinctive stria of Gennari (dense myelinated band in layer IV)
Organized retinotopically with macula having largest representation
Direct projections from lateral geniculate nucleus via optic radiations
function: Performs initial cortical processing of visual information
Detects basic visual features including edges, orientation, and spatial frequency
Organizes input in ocular dominance columns and orientation columns
Damage results in scotomas or cortical blindness corresponding to retinotopic organization

18.name: Secondary Visual Cortex (BA 18)
structure: Surrounds primary visual cortex in occipital lobe
Less prominent stria of Gennari compared to BA 17
Maintains retinotopic organization but with larger receptive fields
Multiple functional subdivisions including V2, V3, and V4 in humans
function: Processes intermediate visual features like contours and motion detection
Contains specialized regions for color processing (V4)
Integrates information from both eyes beyond level of V1
Contributes to figure-ground segregation and border ownership

19.name: Associative Visual Cortex (BA 19)
structure: Located anterior to BA 18 extending into the parieto-occipital and temporal regions
Includes portions of V3, V4, and V5/MT visual areas
Contains neurons with large receptive fields responsive to complex visual features
Connected extensively with parietal and temporal association cortices
function: Processes complex visual features and motion (especially V5/MT)
Integrates visual information for object recognition and spatial awareness
Contributes to visual attention and visual working memory
Damage can result in visual agnosia or specific visual processing deficits

20.name: Inferior Temporal Gyrus (BA 20)
structure: Located on the inferior temporal gyrus, ventral temporal lobe
Granular cortex with well-developed layer IV
Forms part of the ventral visual stream ("what pathway")
Extensive connections with visual association areas and limbic structures
function: Critical for object recognition and visual categorization
Processes complex visual features and contributes to face recognition
Involved in multimodal integration of visual and auditory information
Damage may result in category-specific visual agnosia

21.name: Middle Temporal Gyrus (BA 21)
structure: Located on the middle temporal gyrus, lateral temporal lobe
Typical association cortex with well-developed layers II and IV
Connected with auditory, visual, and multimodal association areas
Forms part of both dorsal and ventral processing streams
function: Processes complex auditory information and language comprehension
Involved in semantic processing and conceptual knowledge
Contributes to biological motion perception and social cognition
Left hemisphere damage associated with lexical-semantic deficits

22.name: Superior Temporal Gyrus (BA 22)
structure: Located on the superior temporal gyrus, includes Wernicke's area in left hemisphere
Granular cortex with well-developed layer IV
Contains primary and association auditory cortex posteriorly
Connected with frontal language areas via arcuate fasciculus
function: Critical for auditory processing and language comprehension
Left posterior STG (Wernicke's area) essential for speech comprehension
Right STG involved in prosody and emotional aspects of language
Damage to left BA 22 results in Wernicke's aphasia with impaired comprehension

23.name: Ventral Posterior Cingulate Cortex (BA 23)
structure: Located in the posterior cingulate gyrus, ventral portion
Granular cortex with well-developed layer IV
Connected with parahippocampal regions and parietal association cortex
Forms part of the default mode network
function: Involved in internally directed cognition and autobiographical memory
Participates in spatial memory and navigation
Contributes to assessment of risk and reward in decision making
Functions as a key node in the default mode network during rest

24.name: Ventral Anterior Cingulate Cortex (BA 24)
structure: Located in the anterior cingulate gyrus, ventral to the genu of corpus callosum
Agranular cortex with poorly developed layer IV
Dense connections with amygdala, PAG, hypothalamus, and autonomic centers
Contains spindle-shaped von Economo neurons
function: Processes emotional aspects of pain and negative affect
Involved in autonomic regulation and visceromotor control
Participates in fear conditioning and emotional learning
Dysfunction associated with mood disorders and chronic pain syndromes

25.name: Subgenual Area (BA 25)
structure: Located beneath the genu of corpus callosum in the medial prefrontal cortex
Agranular/dysgranular transitional cortex
Dense connections with hypothalamus, amygdala, and brainstem autonomic centers
Rich in serotonergic receptors and target for deep brain stimulation
function: Regulates autonomic and endocrine responses to emotional stimuli
Critically involved in mood regulation and stress responses
Contributes to visceromotor control and interoceptive processing
Hyperactivity associated with treatment-resistant depression

26.name: Ectosplenial Portion (BA 26)
structure: Located in the retrosplenial region, around the splenium of corpus callosum
Thin cortex with granular features
Connected with posterior cingulate and parahippocampal regions
Forms part of the posterior limbic system
function: Contributes to spatial navigation and orientation
Involved in episodic memory retrieval
Participates in translating between allocentric and egocentric reference frames
Damage associated with topographical disorientation and navigational deficits

27.name: Piriform Cortex (BA 27)
structure: Located in the anterior parahippocampal gyrus, near uncus
Paleocortex with three layers (characteristic of primary olfactory cortex)
Receives direct projections from olfactory bulb via lateral olfactory tract
Connected with amygdala, entorhinal cortex, and orbitofrontal regions
function: Serves as primary olfactory cortex processing odor information
Involved in olfactory discrimination and identification
Contributes to olfactory memory formation and retrieval
Participates in integration of olfaction with emotional processing

28.name: Ventral Entorhinal Cortex (BA 28)
structure: Located in the anterior parahippocampal gyrus, medial temporal lobe
Transitional cortex with features between iso- and allocortex
Contains distinctive cell islands in layer II (islands of Calleja)
Major interface between neocortex and hippocampal formation
function: Serves as gateway for information flow to and from hippocampus
Critical for episodic memory formation and consolidation
Contains grid cells that map spatial environment
Early site of pathology in Alzheimer's disease

29.name: Retrosplenial Cingulate Cortex (BA 29)
structure: Located in the retrosplenial cortex around splenium of corpus callosum
Granular cortex with distinctive cytochrome oxidase activity
Connected with visual areas, posterior parietal cortex, and hippocampus
Forms part of the default mode network
function: Integrates visual-spatial information with memory
Essential for spatial navigation and orientation
Participates in episodic memory retrieval
Damage associated with anterograde amnesia and topographical disorientation

30.name: Part of Cingulate Cortex (BA 30)
structure: Located in the retrosplenial cortex adjacent to BA 29
Granular cortex with moderate layer IV development
Connected with posterior cingulate, precuneus, and parahippocampal regions
Forms part of posterior medial memory system
function: Contributes to spatial cognition and navigation
Involved in autobiographical memory retrieval
Participates in scene construction and mental imagery
Functions within the default mode network during internal cognition

31.name: Dorsal Posterior Cingulate Cortex (BA 31)
structure: Located in the posterior cingulate gyrus, extends onto medial parietal lobe
Granular cortex with well-developed layer IV
Connected with parietal association cortices and precuneus
Forms core node of the default mode network
function: Involved in internally directed cognition and self-referential thought
Participates in autobiographical memory retrieval
Contributes to monitoring of sensory environment (sentinel function)
Dysfunction implicated in disorders of consciousness

32.name: Dorsal Anterior Cingulate Cortex (BA 32)
structure: Located dorsal to anterior cingulate cortex, extending onto medial frontal surface
Transitional cortex between agranular BA 24 and granular prefrontal cortex
Dense connections with lateral prefrontal, motor, and limbic regions
Rich dopaminergic innervation from ventral tegmental area
function: Critical for performance monitoring and cognitive control
Detects conflicts between competing responses and signals need for control
Involved in error detection and evaluation of outcomes
Participates in attention regulation and task switching

33.name: Part of Anterior Cingulate Cortex (BA 33)
structure: Located in the depth of the callosal sulcus, inferior to the body of corpus callosum
Thin cortex with primitive laminar organization
Connected with other cingulate regions and subcortical autonomic centers
Forms part of the limbic system
function: Contributes to autonomic regulation and visceromotor control
Involved in emotional processing and affective responses
Participates in pain processing particularly emotional aspects
Functionally integrated with adjacent cingulate regions

34.name: Dorsal Entorhinal Cortex (BA 34)
structure: Located in the anterior portion of the parahippocampal gyrus
Transitional cortex between isocortex and allocortex
Connected with olfactory regions, amygdala, and hippocampus
Contains specialized cells forming part of the medial temporal lobe memory system
function: Processes olfactory information integrated with emotional context
Contributes to episodic memory encoding
Participates in spatial navigation with place and grid cells
Forms part of the medial temporal lobe declarative memory system

35.name: Perirhinal Cortex (BA 35)
structure: Located in the anterior parahippocampal gyrus lateral to entorhinal cortex
Transitional cortex with features between isocortex and mesocortex
Connected with sensory association cortices and hippocampal formation
Forms part of the parahippocampal-hippocampal memory system
function: Critical for object recognition memory and familiarity judgments
Involved in associating objects with contexts
Contributes to perceptual processing for complex visual stimuli
Damage results in impaired recognition memory and visual discrimination

36.name: Ectorhinal Area (BA 36)
structure: Located in the lateral fusiform gyrus and inferior temporal gyrus
Granular cortex with well-developed layer IV
Connected with visual association areas and medial temporal structures
Forms part of the ventral visual stream
function: Processes complex visual features for object recognition
Critical for face processing and recognition
Contributes to category-specific visual processing (e.g., places, faces, tools)
Involved in semantic processing and multimodal integration

37.name: Fusiform Gyrus (BA 37)
structure: Located in the fusiform gyrus at the temporo-occipital junction
Granular cortex with well-developed layer IV
Connected with visual areas, language regions, and medial temporal structures
Contains functionally specialized regions including fusiform face area
function: Critical for face recognition (fusiform face area)
Contains regions specialized for recognizing places, bodies, and words
Left hemisphere involved in visual word form processing
Participates in object recognition and visual categorization

38.name: Temporopolar Area (BA 38)
structure: Located at the anterior tip of temporal lobe (temporal pole)
Transitional cortex with features between isocortex and paralimbic cortex
Rich connections with amygdala, orbitofrontal cortex, and insular regions
Forms part of the extended limbic system
function: Integrates complex perceptual inputs with emotional and social contexts
Critical for social cognition and theory of mind
Involved in semantic memory for unique entities and proper names
Damage associated with semantic dementia and socioemotional processing deficits

39.name: Angular Gyrus (BA 39)
structure: Located in the posterior part of inferior parietal lobule
Granular cortex with well-developed layer IV
Connected with visual, auditory, and somatosensory association areas
Forms part of the default mode network
function: Critical for semantic processing and language comprehension
Involved in reading and arithmetic processing
Contributes to attention shifting between different sensory modalities
Left angular gyrus damage results in deficits including alexia and agraphia

40.name: Supramarginal Gyrus (BA 40)
structure: Located in the anterior part of inferior parietal lobule
Granular cortex with well-developed layer IV
Connected with somatosensory, auditory, and premotor regions
Forms part of the dorsal stream for visual processing
function: Processes spatial aspects of sensorimotor integration
Left hemisphere involved in phonological processing and verbal working memory
Contributes to tool use understanding and action observation
Damage to left supramarginal gyrus results in conduction aphasia

41.name: Auditory Cortex (BA 41)
structure: Located on Heschl's gyrus within the lateral sulcus
Koniocortex with densely packed granular layer IV
Receives direct projections from medial geniculate nucleus of thalamus
Organized tonotopically with frequency-specific responses
function: Serves as primary auditory cortex processing basic sound features
Performs spectrotemporal analysis of auditory signals
Processes pitch, intensity, and timing of sounds
Bilateral damage results in cortical deafness

42.name: Auditory Cortex (BA 42)
structure: Located on the lateral portion of the superior temporal gyrus, surrounding BA 41
Less densely granular than BA 41 but still koniocortical features
Connected with primary auditory cortex and auditory association areas
Maintains partial tonotopic organization
function: Functions as secondary auditory cortex
Processes complex sounds and acoustic patterns
Contributes to sound localization and auditory scene analysis
Participates in early stages of speech sound processing

43.name: Primary Gustatory Cortex (BA 43)
structure: Located at the base of the postcentral gyrus near the lateral sulcus
Granular cortex with sensory features
Receives projections from ventral posterior medial nucleus of thalamus
Connected with insula and orbitofrontal gustatory regions
function: Processes basic taste sensations (sweet, sour, salty, bitter, umami)
Encodes intensity and quality of taste stimuli
Integrates taste with somatosensory information from the tongue
Damage can result in ageusia (loss of taste perception)

44.name: Pars Opercularis (BA 44)
structure: Posterior part of the inferior frontal gyrus
Bordered anteriorly by the ascending ramus of the lateral sulcus
Bordered posteriorly by the precentral sulcus
Contains canonical mirror neurons in humans
Densely connected to premotor cortex, primary motor cortex, and superior temporal gyrus
Higher cellular density and more pyramidal cells compared to neighboring regions
function: Forms part of Broca's area in the dominant hemisphere (typically left)
Critical for phonological processing and speech production
Involved in syntactic processing during language comprehension
Essential for verbal working memory
Participates in action observation and imitation networks
Lesions in dominant hemisphere result in Broca's aphasia characterized by non-fluent speech with preserved comprehension

45.name: Pars Triangularis (BA 45)
structure: Triangular region of the inferior frontal gyrus between the anterior and ascending rami of the lateral sulcus
Anterior component of Broca's area in the dominant hemisphere
Rich connections with dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, inferior parietal lobule, and temporal regions
Contains high density of von Economo neurons
Asymmetrical between hemispheres with larger volume typically in the left hemisphere
function: Crucial for semantic processing during language tasks
Involved in sentence comprehension, particularly for complex grammatical structures
Active during lexical retrieval and semantic decision tasks
Participates in response inhibition and cognitive control
Contributes to verbal fluency and controlled semantic retrieval
Damage contributes to certain forms of transcortical motor aphasia

46.name: Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortex (BA 46)
structure: Located in the middle frontal gyrus
Rich reciprocal connections with other prefrontal regions, parietal cortex, and subcortical structures including striatum and thalamus
Higher density of dopaminergic innervation compared to other cortical regions
Well-developed layers II and IV with prominent pyramidal cells in layers III and V
Extensively connected to multimodal association areas
function: Critical hub for executive functions including working memory, cognitive flexibility, and planning
Maintains and manipulates information in working memory
Mediates task switching and adaptation to changing environmental demands
Regulates attention allocation and inhibits inappropriate responses
Important for abstract reasoning and problem-solving
Dysfunction associated with impaired executive function seen in schizophrenia, ADHD, and frontal lobe syndrome

47.name: Pars Orbitalis (BA 47)
structure: Forms the most anterior and ventral part of the inferior frontal gyrus
Located lateral to the orbital surface of the frontal lobe
Connections with limbic structures, orbitofrontal regions, and temporal pole
Less asymmetry between hemispheres compared to other language-related regions
Agranular/dysgranular cortex transitioning to fully granular cortex
function: Involved in processing of emotional prosody in speech
Participates in semantic aspects of language processing
Important for decision-making involving reward evaluation
Active during tasks requiring processing of emotional stimuli
Contributes to social cognition and theory of mind
Damage associated with impaired emotional regulation and social cognition deficits

48.name: Retrosubicular Area (BA 48)
structure: Located posterior to the subiculum in the medial temporal lobe
Transitional zone between hippocampal formation and parahippocampal cortex
Three-layered allocortex transitioning to six-layered isocortex
Rich in interneurons and with distinctive columnar organization
Receives projections from CA1 field of hippocampus and entorhinal cortex
function: Processes spatial and contextual information for memory formation
Involved in consolidation of episodic memories
Participates in spatial navigation circuits
Mediates information flow between hippocampus and neocortex
Important for context-dependent memory retrieval
Dysfunction may contribute to context-inappropriate memory recall seen in PTSD

49.name: Parasubicular Area (BA 49)
structure: Located adjacent to the subiculum in the medial temporal lobe
Part of the hippocampal formation alongside entorhinal cortex
Contains specialized cell types including head direction cells
Strong connections with the entorhinal cortex, presubiculum, and mammillary bodies
Organized in distinct cellular layers with characteristic cytoarchitecture
function: Critical for encoding spatial orientation and head direction
Processes environmental landmark information
Contributes to path integration during navigation
Forms part of the extended hippocampal spatial memory network
Involved in episodic memory formation with spatial components
Lesions associated with topographical disorientation and navigational deficits

52.name: Parainsular Area (BA 52)
structure: Located in the depth of the lateral sulcus adjacent to the insular cortex
Transitional zone between allocortex of insula and isocortex of operculum
Contains agranular and dysgranular cortical regions
Rich in von Economo neurons and fork cells
Receives convergent input from multiple sensory modalities
Connected to limbic structures, thalamus, and sensory association cortices
function: Integrates interoceptive information with external sensory input
Involved in visceral sensory processing and autonomic regulation
Contributes to taste perception and gustatory processing
Participates in multimodal sensory integration
Important for awareness of internal bodily states
Damage may contribute to disorders of interoception and autonomic regulation
